Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in DRMS - The Predictive Power of Beliefs: Testing a Norm-Based Utility Function

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of the present work is to test an operationalization of norms proposed by Dr. Cristina Bicchieri, which embeds this concept into the rational actor model from decision theory. In a series of two studies, the researchers will test whether two often-cited effects in the social dilemma literature (the influence of social cues and group membership) can be accounted for by their impact on participants' beliefs about the existing social norm, as defined by Dr. Bicchieri and measured using procedures she developed. In a third study, the researchers will test the ability of Dr. Bicchieri's norm-based utility function to predict cooperation behavior across social dilemma tasks. If successful, this would support the usefulness of embedding norms into the rational choice model (as behavioral economists have been doing with other "social preferences"). Lastly, a fourth study will test Dr. Bicchieri's claim that the norms that solve coordination problems (where self and social interests dovetail) are sustained via a different mechanism than those that solve social dilemmas (where self and social interests diverge). In particular, we will observe whether third-party reward, punishment, and compensation behavior differs as a function of the type of norm necessary to reach the socially optimal outcome. Evidence in line with our predictions would support Dr. Bicchieri?s dichotomy of norms into two types and present another method for detecting the existence of norms other than belief elicitation.

The norms of an environment influence people's expectations about what is commonly done and what is commonly approved or disapproved. These expectations can subsequently influence a person's actions as norm-abiding behavior is informally rewarded and violations are punished (starting with gossip, ostracism, and then exclusion). From a policy perspective, efforts aimed at improving the welfare of society by introducing formal rules will benefit from an examination of the current informal rules governing a group's actions. To the extent that the existing informal rules legitimize the formal ones, the cost of enforcing the new formal rules will be lower and vice versa. However, the concept of norms remains imprecise, and real-world applications remain infeasible, without an operational definition and a model of their impact on behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From a very early age, and possibly to a degree not observed in other primates, humans begin representing and being influenced by the beliefs and practices of people around them. This tendency, along with others, leads to the emergence and maintenance of culturally specific norms – rules of behavior that are a function of what is commonly done and/or what is commonly approved and disapproved by relevant group members. Norms dictate everything from the conventions of fashion to the rituals of religion, but the current work focuses on their particular influence in social dilemmas – situations in which personal interests are at odds with collective interests. Common examples of social dilemmas involve public stewardship such as whether or not to overfish from public waters, clean up litter in a housing project, reduce water consumption during a shortage, or vote in a national election. In these domains, the dynamics of social norms, including norm-enforcement mechanisms such as gossip, ostracism, and exclusion, may sustain cooperation towards collective welfare. However, evaluating this claim requires a formal definition of norms and a theory of their impact on behavior.  The purpose of this NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant was to enable Jeff DeWitt to complete his dissertation work testing a specific account of social norms proposed by Dr. Cristina Bicchieri in her 2006 book, The Grammar of Society: The Nature and Dynamics of Social Norms.

By providing the conditions under which different types of norms should exist and be followed, Bicchieri (2006) offers a method for testing whether norms are indeed maintaining social practices society wishes to change, such as genital mutilation or child marriage.  In addition, her definitions and measurement techniques provide a means for assessing the effectiveness of interventions aimed at changing well-entrenched norms by checking for corresponding changes in beliefs about the prevailing norm in one's group.  To evaluate the usefulness of Bicchieri's (2006) conceptual and operational definitions, Jeff designed and implemented three social experiments where participants made choices that would affect their own monetary payment from the task as well as the payment of another participant.  The payments associated with each possible choice were designed to create the structure of a social dilemma - one choice always resulted in the highest personal payment, while the other choice maximized the collective payment to all parties involved (if everyone cooperated in choosing it).  Across different experimental settings, we found significant support for Bicchieri's (2006) definitions and measurement techniques - there was a robust relationship between a participant's beliefs about the actions and beliefs of other participants and their own behavior (even when they were incentivized to be as accurate in their predictions as possible).  These findings support the use of Bicchieri's definitions in real-world social dilemmas which could have a broad impact on society.  In particular, efforts aimed at improving the welfare of society by introducing formal (i.e. legal) rules to change behavior will benefit from an examination of the current informal norms governing a group’s actions using Bicchieri's approach.  To the extent that the existing informal rules legitimize the formal ones, the cost of enforcing the new formal rules will be lower and vice versa.

In addition to testing Bicchieri's definitions, Jeff's studies also examined Bicchieri's broader claim that social decision making is context-dependent (by being conditional on beliefs about the prevailing norms in one's environment). This issue is crucial to scientists in the fields of psychology and behavioral economics because the mainstream approach posits that individuals have much more stable "social preferences." However, if the source of consistent “social preferences” remains a motivation to conform to and uphold social norms, then simply defining the prevailing norm as part of each individual's objective function (i.e. utility function) will lead to incorrect predictions across different domains, social groups, or time periods.  A fourth study was designed to directly test this claim by experimentally manipulating norms instead of simply measuring them, but its results were inconclusive.  However, the predictive power of norms in our first three studies provides indirect support for adopting a more context-dependent theory of social decision making.
